A Taxonomy and Comparative Analysis of IPv4 ID Selection Correctness, Security, and Performance

Abstract.

The battle for a more secure Internet is waged on many fronts, including the most basic of networking protocols. Our focus is the IPv4 Identifier (IPID), an IPv4 header field as old as the Internet with an equally long history as an exploited side channel for scanning network properties, inferring off-path connections, and poisoning DNS caches. This article taxonomizes the 25-year history of IPID-based exploits and the corresponding changes to IPID selection methods. By mathematically analyzing these methodsâ€™ correctness and security and empirically evaluating their performance, we reveal recommendations for best practice as well as shortcomings of current operating system implementations, emphasizing the value of systematic evaluations in network security.

IP identifiers, side channels, comparative analysis, probability theory

1. Introduction

There is ongoing interplay between operating system (OS) developers implementing basic networking protocols, such as IP and TCP, and security researchers discovering side channels and vulnerabilities in those diverse implementations. A prime example is IP fragmentation and reassembly, a staple of Internet functionality for over forty yearsÂ (Postel, 1981). When an IPv4 packet is too large for the next link of its routing path, it is fragmented; a destination machine then reassembles fragments it receives based on their IPv4 Identifiers (IPIDs), a 16-bit header field. OSes are free to assign IPIDs to packets however they want, so long as they avoid causing ambiguous reassembly by sending multiple packets with the same IPID to the same destination close in time.

Despite early concerns about IP fragmentationâ€™s performance impactsÂ (Kent and Mogul, 1987) and later concerns about its vulnerabilitiesÂ (Herzberg and Shulman, 2013a; Gilad and Herzberg, 2013), its central role in the Internetâ€”and in DNS in particularâ€”continues to drive the discovery of new vulnerabilities in IPID selection methods. Since 1998, numerous exploits have abused these methods to poison DNS cachesÂ (Herzberg and Shulman, 2013a; Palmer and Somers, 2019; Zheng etÂ al., 2020), hijack TCP connectionsÂ (Feng etÂ al., 2020, 2022; Gilad and Herzberg, 2012), launch denial-of-service (DoS) attacksÂ (Malhotra etÂ al., 2016), scan portsÂ (antirez, 1998; Zhang etÂ al., 2018), detect and measure connectionsÂ (Knockel and Crandall, 2014; Alexander etÂ al., 2019), detect Internet censorshipÂ (Ensafi etÂ al., 2014), and create covert channelsÂ (Klein, 2022)â€”all from off-path vantage points requiring nothing more than an active Internet connection. Understanding the aims and necessary conditions of these diverse exploits is critical for proactively securing the menagerie of existing IPID selection methods from further misuse.

The purpose of this survey is two-fold. First, we taxonomize the 25-year history of off-path IPID-based exploits and the subsequent changes to IPID selection methods across all major OSes. This taxonomy categorizes every known exploit as either a probe comparison that tracks changes in IPIDs over time to infer information about other machines, or a fragment injection that uses guessed IPIDs to trick a target machine into replacing legitimate fragments with malicious ones during reassembly. For each class of exploits, we identify the archetypal approach and resulting necessary conditions for success, thus distilling the key properties of (in)secure IPID selection methods.

Second, we perform a unifying comparative analysis of all \replacedsevensix major IPID selection methods across three qualities: correctness (does the method support unambiguous fragment reassembly?), security (are sequences of IPID values sufficiently difficult to predict?), and performance (what are the methodâ€™s time and space complexities?). By parameterizing this analysis in terms of a machineâ€™s expected rate of traffic and number of CPUs, we reveal tradeoffs among the selection methods for different use cases (e.g., a high-traffic DNS server vs.Â a low-traffic home computer).Â Among these evaluations, the most surprising is that globally incrementing selectionâ€”the first, simplest, and most dismissed of all IPID selection methodsâ€”is in fact the most secure and performant choice for non-connection-bound packets when the rate of outgoing packets is high. We conclude by proposing a new approach to IPID selection that shifts away from OSes implementing a single method that necessarily compromises at least one of correctness, security, or performance across different use cases, instead embracing multiple implementations that end users can choose from (e.g., as a network setting) based on their expected rates of traffic.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. SectionÂ 2 introduces IP fragmentation and reassembly, the \replacedsevensix primary IPID selection methods, and their current OS implementations. SectionÂ 3 reviews the history of exploits using IPIDs for measurements or malicious attacks and the corresponding changes to selection methods. SectionÂ 4 presents our comparative analysis of IPID selection methodsâ€™ correctness, security, and performance. We synthesize these evaluations as recommendations for a new approach to IPID selection in SectionÂ 5; readers seeking to quickly digest â€œwhatâ€™s newâ€ should skip to this section and refer to Fig.Â 9 as a visual summary of our proposed approach. Finally, we conclude in SectionÂ 6.

2. Background

We begin by reviewing how IPIDs are used, the established methods for selecting IPIDs, and the current OS implementations of those selection methods.

2.1. IP Packet Fragmentation and Reassembly

The IPID is a 16-bit IP header field used for packet reassembly (see Fig.Â 1). Every IP packet is assigned an IPID by its sender. If ever a packet is too large for some link of its routing path, an intermediate router breaks it into fragments that inherit the IPID of their packet. As the packetâ€™s destination receives these fragments in its reassembly buffer (also known as the fragmentation cache), it uses their IPIDs to group them by packet and inspects their Flags and Fragment Offset IP header fields to determine whether all of the packetâ€™s fragments have arrived and in what order they should be reassembled. This continues until the packet is reassembled or a timeout of 15â€“120 seconds is reachedÂ (Braden, 1989; Postel, 1981). The main restriction concerning IPID selection is that IPIDs must be â€œuniqueâ€ to avoid ambiguous reassemblyÂ (Postel, 1981).

IP fragmentation is not always necessary. For example, if a sender knows a pathâ€™s maximum transmission unit (MTU)â€”e.g., as part of a TCP connectionâ€”it can resize its packets prior to sending them. Such packets can be made atomic to discourage IP fragmentation, setting their Donâ€™t Fragment (DF) flag to true, their More Fragments (MF) flag to false, and their Fragment Offset to 0. IPIDs have no utility in atomic packets and are thus ignored and allowed to be any valueÂ (Touch, 2013).

2.2. IPID Selection Methods

In this section, we detail the \replacedsevensix existing methods for selecting packetsâ€™ IPIDs. These methods fall into two categories: counter-based (SectionÂ 2.2.1) and PRNG-based (SectionÂ 2.2.2).

2.2.1. Counter-Based Selection Methods

  • â€¢

    Globally incrementing IPID selection is the earliest and simplest method. Each machine maintains a single, sequentially-incrementing, 16-bit counter for all IPID generation. Whenever a machine sends a packet, it increments its global counter (modulo 216superscript2162^{16}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) and uses the resulting value as the packetâ€™s IPID.

  • â€¢

    Per-connection IPID selection generalizes globally incrementing selection by maintaining one sequentially-incrementing 16-bit counter per active connection, i.e., a 5-tuple specifying the source and destination IP addresses, source and destination ports, and protocol number. Each connection counter is initialized with a random value when the connection is established and subsequently assigns IPIDs to packets by incrementing by one, modulo 216superscript2162^{16}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  • â€¢

    Per-destination IPID selection is analogous to per-connection selection, but with one counter per pair of source and destination IP addresses.

  • â€¢

    Per-bucket IPID selection is similar to per-connection and per-destination selection, but with one counter per â€œbucketâ€. Packets are typically mapped to buckets by hashing their IP header information (e.g., source and destination IP addresses or the protocol number) with cryptographic information like secret keys. Some implementations of per-bucket selection use sequentially-incrementing bucket counters, analogous to the above methods, while others inject some stochasticity. These variations are detailed by OS in SectionÂ 2.3.

2.2.2. PRNG-Based Selection Methods

Methods based on pseudorandom number generation (PRNGs) select IPID values at random from among the 216superscript2162^{16}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT possible values \addedoften while avoiding recently selected IPIDs whose reuse could cause ambiguous reassembly. One method is to generate IPID values with a well-seeded PRNG algorithm while maintaining a searchable queue storing the last kâ‰¥0ğ‘˜0k\geq 0italic_k â‰¥ 0 unique IPIDs. When an IPID is requested, the PRNG generates values until one is found that is not already in the queue; this new value is then inserted into the queue and used as the next IPID. The size of the searchable queue varies by implementation, but is typically chosen between 4,096 and 32,768 (i.e., 212superscript2122^{12}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 215superscript2152^{15}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) to provide a good tradeoff between entropy and non-repetition.

Another method uses an iterated Knuth shuffleÂ (Knuth, 1969) (also known as the Durstenfeld algorithm for random permutations or the Fisherâ€“Yates shuffle). Initially, a random permutation of all 216superscript2162^{16}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT IPID values is generated by a standard Knuth shuffle. When an IPID is requested, the next value in the permutation is used. That value is then swapped into a position chosen uniformly at random from among the previous 216âˆ’ksuperscript216ğ‘˜2^{16}-k2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k positions in the permutation (including its own), ensuring that it will not be selected again within the next kğ‘˜kitalic_k requests for IPIDs.

\added

Pure PRNG selection simply generates IPIDs from among the 216superscript2162^{16}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT possible values uniformly at random, regardless of possibly repeating IPIDs. This is functionally equivalent to the previous two methods with k=0ğ‘˜0k=0italic_k = 0, but has no need for their data structures ensuring non-repetition.

2.3. Current Implementations

In this section, we survey current implementations of IPID selection across popular OSes.

Windows

Source code for Windows 8, 10, and 11 is not publicly available, though reverse-engineering efforts revealed that until related issues were patched in 2019, Windows 8 and 10 used per-bucket IPID selection based on the Toeplitz hash function with 8,192 (i.e., 213superscript2132^{13}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 13 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) bucketsÂ (Klein and Pinkas, 2019). Recent analysis shows that Windows Server (v1903) uses per-destination IPID selectionÂ (Klein, 2022). Specifically, Windows maintains a \replacedâ€œPathSetâ€ (i.e., a hash table)hash table of sequentially incrementing counters indexed by source and destination IP address pairs, adding \replaceda new counternew entries whenever a packetâ€™s destination is not already in the \replacedPathSethash table. \replacedThe PathSetâ€™s size is checked every 0.5Â s: if it has grown beyond its â€œpurge thresholdâ€â€”4,096 (i.e., 212superscript2122^{12}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) counters in Windows 10 or 32,768 (i.e., 215superscript2152^{15}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) in Windows Serverâ€”or more than 5,000 counters have been added since the last check, a â€œpurge sequenceâ€ removes up to maxâ¡{1,000,# added since last check}1000# added since last check\max\{\numprint{1000},\text{\# added since last check}\}roman_max { 1 , 000 , # added since last check } â€œstaleâ€ counters. Counters are considered â€œstaleâ€ depending on when they were last accessed and the PathSetâ€™s size: if the PathSetâ€™s size is between once and twice its purge threshold, then counters accessed longer than 10Â s (Windows 10) or 60Â s (Windows Server) ago are considered stale; if the PathSetâ€™s size is more than twice its purge threshold, all counters are considered staleÂ (Klein, 2024).When this table grows too large or too quickly, a â€œpurge sequenceâ€ scans over the table and removes any â€œstaleâ€ counters accessed longer than 10â€“60Â s ago.

Linux

The current Linux kernel (v6.9) uses either per-connection or per-bucket IPID selection depending on the connection type. Packets sent via established sockets use per-connection selection, initializing connection counters with a random value generated by prandom_u32 after the connection is established. Atomic packets sent outside of sockets and any RST response to an unsolicited packet (e.g., a stray SYN/ACK) are assigned IPID zeroÂ (Alexander etÂ al., 2019). All other packets use per-bucket selection with 2,048 to 262,144 (i.e., 211superscript2112^{11}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 218superscript2182^{18}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 18 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) buckets, depending on the senderâ€™s RAM. Buckets are located using SipHash-2-4 to hash the packetâ€™s destination IP address, source IP address, protocol number, and a \replaced128-bit64-bit random key. Instead of incrementing bucket counters sequentially, Linux increments by a value chosen uniformly at random from 1 to the number of system ticks since the bucket counter was last incremented. These stochastic increments were designed to add noise to unused bucket counters that adversaries could otherwise take advantage of.

OpenBSD

OpenBSD (v7.5) implements PRNG IPID selection using an iterated Knuth shuffle with k=32,768ğ‘˜32768k=\numprint{32768}italic_k = 32 , 768 (i.e., 215superscript2152^{15}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). Random swap indices are generated using arc4rand. OpenBSD never assigns zero as an IPID: if zero is next in the permutation, it is swapped as usual but not returned.

FreeBSD

FreeBSD (v14.0) assigns IPID zero to all atomic packets and uses globally incrementing selection for non-atomic packets. FreeBSD includes a configuration option to use PRNG selection with a searchable queue of size k=8,192ğ‘˜8192k=\numprint{8192}italic_k = 8 , 192 (i.e., 213superscript2132^{13}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 13 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) instead, though it is disabled by default to minimize performance impact. This disabled code uses arc4rand as its PRNG. As in OpenBSD, zero is treated as a special IPID that is never returned.

macOS/XNU

Although most source code for macOS is not publicly available, its network stack uses the open source XNU kernel (\replacedv8792.41.9v7195.121.3)\deleted which borrows heavily from FreeBSD. As in FreeBSD, macOS/XNU assigns zero as the IPID of all atomic packets\deleted and includes a configuration option to use either globally incrementing or PRNG selection with a searchable queue of size 4,096 (i.e., 212superscript2122^{12}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) for non-atomic packets. Unlike FreeBSD, XNU sets PRNG selection as its default, though the exact PRNG algorithm being used is excluded from the publicly available source code. \addedFor non-atomic packets, macOS recently adopted pure PRNG selection, generating 16-bit values uniformly at random and then salting them with a packet-specific value; notably, this implementation does not include mechanisms for avoiding repeated IPIDs. As in the BSDs, zero is treated as a special IPID that is never returned. \deletedBy probing a machine running macOS 12 (Monterey), we confirmed that atomic packets are always assigned IPID zero and non-atomic packets appear to have random IPIDs.

3. Measurements and Attacks

In this section, we present a history of IPID-based exploits and the corresponding OS implementation changes they influenced (see Fig.Â 2 for an overview). Notably, many vulnerabilities remained exploitable long after disclosure due to delays in patching and updating to the latest versions. We categorize these exploits as either probe comparisons (SectionÂ 3.1) or fragment injections (SectionÂ 3.2) based on how they use IPIDs to achieve their goals. Within these categories, we distinguish between measurements which infer information about other machines and attacks which maliciously affect target systemsâ€”often by leveraging information learned from measurements.

Network exploits by a machine Mğ‘€Mitalic_M against target machines Ağ´Aitalic_A and BğµBitalic_B are performed from one of three vantage points: off-path, on-path, or in-pathÂ (Marczak etÂ al., 2015). If Mğ‘€Mitalic_M is off-path, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M does not receive any traffic between Ağ´Aitalic_A and BğµBitalic_B. Instead, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M must actively probe these machines by sending them packets and inspecting their responses to learn anything about their states. An on-path machine passively receives all traffic between Ağ´Aitalic_A and BğµBitalic_B but cannot modify it directly; an in-path machine (i.e., a â€œman-in-the-middleâ€) receives and can modify all traffic between Ağ´Aitalic_A and BğµBitalic_B. For example, if an ISP were to forward copies of its traffic to its government, the ISP is in-path and the government is on-path. We are primarily concerned with off-path exploits, since these rely on side channels like IPIDs for information. They are also the most powerful in practice, since they are usable by any unprivileged adversary without ISP or nation-state control over network infrastructure.

3.1. Probe Comparisons

A probe comparison tracks changes in IPIDs over time to infer information about other machines. As such, most probe comparisons are measurements. The inferred information is typically binary: whether a target port is open or closed, a firewall is performing egress or ingress filtering, a guessed secret value is correct or incorrect, and so on. Probe comparisons come in many forms, but the archetypal approach for an off-path measurer or attacker works as follows:

  1. (1)

    Probe the target machineâ€™s relevant IPID, obtaining value xğ‘¥xitalic_x.

  2. (2)

    Interact with the target machine such that its IPID values change one way if the inferred information is â€œtrueâ€ (e.g., the target port is open, a firewall is performing egress filtering, a guessed secret value is correct, etc.) and some other way otherwise.

  3. (3)

    Probe the target machineâ€™s relevant IPID again, obtaining a new value yğ‘¦yitalic_y.

  4. (4)

    Based on the interactions in Step (2), compare xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y to gather evidence about whether the inferred information is â€œtrueâ€. Repeat Steps (1)â€“(3) as needed to gain statistical confidence.

From this outline, we can characterize two necessary conditions for successful probe comparisons:

  1. (PC1)

    A measurer or attacker must be able to probe and interact with a target machineâ€™s relevant IPID selection mechanism, either directly or indirectly, in a timely manner.

  2. (PC2)

    A measurer or attacker must be able to correlate its interactions with the target machine to observable changes in the target machineâ€™s IPID values.

The remainder of this section summarizes seven probe comparison exploits, including idle scans (SectionÂ 3.1.1), triangular spamming (SectionÂ 3.1.2), on-path NAT measurements (SectionÂ 3.1.3), canary fragments (SectionÂ 3.1.4), bucket leaks (SectionÂ 3.1.5), TCP injection attacks (SectionÂ 3.1.6), and covert channels (SectionÂ 3.1.7).

3.1.1. Idle Scans

The earliest known IPID-based measurement is the idle scan which exploits the predictability of globally incrementing IPIDs to reveal off-path connectionsÂ (antirez, 1998; de Vivo etÂ al., 1999; Handley etÂ al., 2001) (Fig.Â 2A). An off-path measurer Mğ‘€Mitalic_M can learn whether a target machine Tğ‘‡Titalic_T has a certain port open by probing the IPIDs of an intermediate â€œzombieâ€ machine Zğ‘Zitalic_Z with low traffic rates (Fig.Â 3). First, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M sends Zğ‘Zitalic_Z an unsolicited SYN/ACK packet, to which Zğ‘Zitalic_Z replies with an RST packet that contains its current IPID, say xğ‘¥xitalic_x. Machine Mğ‘€Mitalic_M then sends a spoofed SYN packet to Tğ‘‡Titalic_T appearing to originate from Zğ‘Zitalic_Z that specifies the target port it wants to scan. If this port is closed, nothing comes of this spoofed packet (Fig.Â 3(a)); otherwise, if it is open, Tğ‘‡Titalic_T replies to Zğ‘Zitalic_Z with a SYN/ACK, which in turn causes Zğ‘Zitalic_Z to reply to Tğ‘‡Titalic_T with an RST containing an incremented IPID (Fig.Â 3(b)). Finally, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M again sends Zğ‘Zitalic_Z an unsolicited SYN/ACK and inspects the incremented IPID yğ‘¦yitalic_y of the RST reply. If yâ‰¡x+2mod216ğ‘¦moduloğ‘¥2superscript216y\equiv x+2\bmod 2^{16}italic_y â‰¡ italic_x + 2 roman_mod 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M concludes the target port is open; otherwise, if yâ‰¡x+1mod216ğ‘¦moduloğ‘¥1superscript216y\equiv x+1\bmod 2^{16}italic_y â‰¡ italic_x + 1 roman_mod 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, it concludes the port is closed or filtered.

As a result of the idle scanâ€™s disclosure, OpenBSD, FreeBSD, and XNU replaced their globally incrementing IPIDs with PRNG selection using Linear Congruential Generators (LCGs) \addedwith additional complication layers. These implementations lasted until 2007 when KleinÂ (Klein, 2007) (Fig.Â 2E) demonstrated that the â€œrandomâ€ values produced by LCGs could be predicted, once again making idle scans possible. In response, OpenBSD replaced LCGs with an iterated Knuth shuffle (see OpenBSD commit 4fd19f) while FreeBSDâ€”and later, XNUâ€”chose PRNG selection using searchable queues (see FreeBSD commit 361021 and XNU commit ff3a0c). These implementations remain largely unchanged since their appearances in 2008. Linux took a different approach, implementing a hybrid of per-connection selection (for atomic packets) and per-destination selection (for non-atomic packets). Windows retained globally incrementing IPIDs until Windows 8, which was released in 2012Â (Orevi etÂ al., 2018).

Despite these changes, delayed patching gave ample opportunity for the idle scanâ€™s wide adoption and refinement. Nmap integrated it as a scanning option in 2001Â (Lyon, 2009). Chen et al.Â (Chen etÂ al., 2005) (Fig.Â 2C) introduced an extension that additionally inferred packet loss, duplication, and arrival order; server traffic rates; and the number of servers in a load-balanced deployment. Later, Ensafi et al.Â (Ensafi etÂ al., 2014) (Fig.Â 2L) improved the idle scan to detect off-path SYN/ACK and RST filtering between machinesÂ (Ensafi etÂ al., 2010), which in turn was leveraged for Internet-wide censorship measurementÂ (Ensafi, 2014; Ensafi etÂ al., 2015; Pearce etÂ al., 2017) (Fig.Â 2P).

3.1.2. Triangular Spamming

Qian et al.Â (Qian etÂ al., 2010) (Fig.Â 2F) formalized triangular spamming, a technique for email spam where a high-bandwidth spammer uses low-bandwidth relay bots to send spam to a target mail server. By spoofing spam from the relay bots to the mail server, the spammer conceals its own IP address, thus protecting itself from IP block-listing. For this attack to succeed, the relay bot(s) must receive any SMTP responses from the mail server (typically sent on port 25) and forward them to the spammer (using some other port). ISPs commonly mitigate spam by blocking outgoing SMTP traffic on port 25 (i.e., egress filtering), stopping machines behind their firewall from participating in spam as relay bots. Thus, identifying potential relay bot(s) for triangular spamming reduces to finding ISPs that do not block incoming (i.e., ingress) SMTP traffic.

If a potential relay bot Rğ‘…Ritalic_R uses globally incrementing IPIDs, this can be determined using a simple probe comparison. The attacker Ağ´Aitalic_A first probes Rğ‘…Ritalic_R with an unsolicited SYN/ACK on port 80 and records the IPID xğ‘¥xitalic_x of the RST reply. It then sends a large burst of sâ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘ 1s\gg 1italic_s â‰« 1 probes on port 25 whichâ€”if inbound traffic is not blocked by the ISPâ€”each increment the global IPID counter on Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. Finally, Ağ´Aitalic_A again probes Rğ‘…Ritalic_R on port 80 to obtain its updated IPID yğ‘¦yitalic_y. If yâ‰ˆx+1mod216ğ‘¦moduloğ‘¥1superscript216y\approx x+1\bmod 2^{16}italic_y â‰ˆ italic_x + 1 roman_mod 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the ISP is likely blocking inbound traffic; otherwise, if yâ‰ˆx+smod216ğ‘¦moduloğ‘¥ğ‘ superscript216y\approx x+s\bmod 2^{16}italic_y â‰ˆ italic_x + italic_s roman_mod 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the relay bot is receiving packets on port 25 and can be used in triangular spamming.

3.1.3. On-Path NAT Measurements

It was once assumed that network address translation (NAT)Â (Srisuresh and Holdrege, 1999) obfuscated devices in a local network behind a shared public IP address, stopping external observers on the public network from counting or identifying NATted devices or distinguishing their traffic. However, early NAT devices did not change outgoing packetsâ€™ IPIDs. BellovinÂ (Bellovin, 2002) (Fig.Â 2B) showed how this could be exploited for on-path measurement (e.g., by an ISP that sees all NATted traffic but doesnâ€™t manipulate it) if consecutive IPIDs assigned by the same NATted device are correlated. Notably, this on-path vantage point eliminates the need for probe comparisonâ€™s probing and interaction steps, simplifying it to comparing IPIDs over time. First, the on-path measurer collects all traffic from a target NAT over a period of time. It then builds sequences of IPIDs that likely originated from the same NATted device by inspecting packetsâ€™ IPIDs in time order and either appending them to the â€œbest matchâ€ existing sequence or starting a new sequence if none match. The resulting number of sequences is often a good approximation of the number of NATted devices.

Bellovinâ€™s matching rules for constructing IPID sequences are based on globally incrementing IPIDs, but could easily extend to any counter-based method by changing parameters. Thus, the paperâ€™s suggested mitigations included using a PRNG-based selection method. Surprisingly, this protection alone is insufficient; Mongkolluksamee et al.Â (Mongkolluksamee etÂ al., 2012) (Fig.Â 2I) later extended this on-path measurement to uniquely identify NATted devices and their OSes across all IPID selection methods by additionally observing patterns in the TCP sequence number and source port.

3.1.4. Canary Fragments

For 14 years, Linuxâ€™s per-destination IPIDs for non-atomic packets seemed impervious to probe comparisons. If an off-path measurer Mğ‘€Mitalic_M probes the per-destination counter on a server Sğ‘†Sitalic_S for some client Cğ¶Citalic_C by spoofing a packet from Cğ¶Citalic_C to Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, the server Sğ‘†Sitalic_S replies to Cğ¶Citalic_C, not Mğ‘€Mitalic_M. But this intuition also reveals a weakness: every increment of a per-destination counter is caused by a packet sent to its unique destination. Knockel and CrandallÂ (Knockel and Crandall, 2014) (Fig.Â 2N) recognized that this could be abused to detect if Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and Cğ¶Citalic_C are communicating and, if so, count the number of ICMP, UDP, or TCP packets exchanged between them. First, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M fills the reassembly buffer of Cğ¶Citalic_C with canary fragments containing guessed IPIDs that appear to originate from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S (Fig.Â 4). Second, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M spoofs large ICMP ECHO requests from Cğ¶Citalic_C to Sğ‘†Sitalic_S which become fragmented ICMP ECHO responses from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S to Cğ¶Citalic_C. If any canary has an IPID matching an ECHO response, it is evicted from the reassembly buffer. Finally, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M â€œqueriesâ€ the reassembly buffer of Cğ¶Citalic_C to determine if many canaries are missing; if so, their guessed IPIDs were correct. By repeating this measurement over time and tracking the change in IPIDs, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M can count the number of packets sent from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S to Cğ¶Citalic_C.

When canary fragments were disclosed, the Linux developers had already been working to replace per-destination selectionâ€”due to its large performance impact on modern serversâ€”with per-bucket selection using a Jenkins hash of the destination IP address (see Linux commit 73f156). To curb canary fragmentsâ€™ abuse of per-destination countersâ€™ perfect increments-to-packets correlation, they also added the stochastic increments described in SectionÂ 2.3 and included the source IP address and protocol number in the bucket hash input (see Linux commit 04ca69).

Hybrid Leaks

Alexander et al.Â (Alexander etÂ al., 2019) (Fig.Â 2S) introduced hybrid leaks, a measurement that detects active TCP connections between a Linux server Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and any of its clients Cğ¶Citalic_C by differentiating between Linuxâ€™s hybrid modes of per-bucket and per-connection selection. First, a measurer Mğ‘€Mitalic_M finds a hash collision with Cğ¶Citalic_C on Sğ‘†Sitalic_S using a simplified version of the Zhang et al.Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2018) method described above. It then sends an unsolicited SYN/ACK to Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and obtains the current per-bucket IPID xğ‘¥xitalic_x from the RST reply. Next, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M spoofs s>1ğ‘ 1s>1italic_s > 1 SYN/ACKs from Cğ¶Citalic_C to Sğ‘†Sitalic_S containing a guessed source port and a standard TCP destination port (i.e., 80 or 443). If Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and Cğ¶Citalic_C have an active TCP connection on those ports, Sğ‘†Sitalic_S replies to Cğ¶Citalic_C with a single â€œchallenge ACKâ€ whose IPID is drawn from their per-connection counter. Otherwise, Sğ‘†Sitalic_S replies to Cğ¶Citalic_C with sğ‘ sitalic_s RST packets whose IPIDs each increment the per-bucket counter. Finally, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M probes the updated per-bucket IPID yğ‘¦yitalic_y. Assuming Mğ‘€Mitalic_M sends its packets fast enough to avoid the per-bucket counterâ€™s stochastic increments, yâˆ’xmod216<smoduloğ‘¦ğ‘¥superscript216ğ‘ y-x\bmod 2^{16}<sitalic_y - italic_x roman_mod 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_s is evidence that Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and Cğ¶Citalic_C have an active connection.

Linux mitigated this probe comparison measurementâ€”and others depending on unsolicited SYN/ACK probes and their RST repliesÂ (antirez, 1998; lkm, 2007; Qian etÂ al., 2010; Zhang etÂ al., 2018)â€”by replying to any unsolicited SYN/ACK with an RST whose IPID is zero (see Linux commit 431280).

Device Fingerprinting

Klein and PinkasÂ (Klein and Pinkas, 2019) (Fig.Â 2U) exfiltrated the secret keys Windows and Linux used in their bucket hashes, enabling a measurer to fingerprint and track a device as well as predict all per-bucket countersâ€™ IPIDs. In response, Linux increased their key size to 128 bits and updated their hash function to SipHash-2-4, which remains their current implementation (see Linux commit df4537). Notably, Windows chose to address this issue by replacing per-bucket selection with per-destinationÂ (Klein, 2022) which, as already discussed in SectionÂ 3.1.4, has a high performance impact and has been exploited successfully beforeÂ (Knockel and Crandall, 2014; Malhotra etÂ al., 2016). Since Windows is closed-source, it remains unclear if analogous measurements would succeed against their current implementation.

3.1.6. TCP Injection Attacks

In a TCP injection attack, an attacker inserts malicious traffic into an active TCP connection between a client and server. To do so, the attacker needs to know the client and serverâ€™s IP addresses and TCP ports along with the current TCP sequence number of the machine the attacker is spoofing. Most attacks assume the two IP addresses are known and the server is using a standard port for TCP (e.g., 80 or 443), leaving the clientâ€™s port and sequence number as the two unknowns. But if the client uses globally incrementing IPIDs, an off-path attacker can learn the clientâ€™s port and sequence number through a port comparison guess-and-checkÂ (lkm, 2007) (Fig.Â 2D). The attacker (1) probes the clientâ€™s IPID, say xğ‘¥xitalic_x, (2) sends packets that are specifically crafted to make the client increment its IPID if and only if its guessed port or sequence number is correct, (3) probes the clientâ€™s new IPID, say yğ‘¦yitalic_y, and (4) compares xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y to determine the accuracy of its guess. Just like for idle scans (SectionÂ 3.1.1), this attackâ€™s second step depends critically on the connection having little traffic, since other packets incrementing the clientâ€™s IPID would confuse the results. However, Gilad and HerzbergÂ (Gilad and Herzberg, 2012, 2014) (Fig.Â 2J,M) showed that with a â€œpuppetâ€ on the client (e.g., a malicious script in a browser sandbox), this attack can succeed even on noisier connections.

Naturally, the defense against this guess-and-check technique and the resulting TCP injections is to use an IPID selection method that is less predictable or harder for an attacker to access. However, this must be done on all machines involved in the connection, not just the client. Qian and MaoÂ (Qian and Mao, 2012) (Fig.Â 2H) showed that even if a clientâ€™s IPIDs are difficult to predict, a firewall or middlebox using globally incrementing IPIDs can leak the sequence numbers necessary for TCP injection.

The state-of-the-art attacks remained specific to globally incrementing IPIDs for 13 years, until Feng et al.Â (Feng etÂ al., 2020, 2022) (Fig.Â 2W,Y) introduced their novel downgrade attacks to achieve TCP injection against Linuxâ€™s hybrid per-connection/per-bucket IPIDs. Recall that when guess-and-checking the clientâ€™s TCP port and sequence numbers, the attacker needs to probe the clientâ€™s relevant IPIDs. But it is impossible for the attacker to probe the per-connection counter specific to this clientâ€“serverâ€™s active TCP connection unless it had the very information itâ€™s trying to leak. Instead, Feng et al.Â observe that per-connection selection can be downgraded to per-bucket selection by spoofing ICMP â€œFragmentation Neededâ€ packets from the client to the server, tricking it into clearing its responsesâ€™ DF flags and thus demoting otherwise atomic packets to non-atomic. The clientâ€™s corresponding bucket counter can then be identified and probed using the hash collision techniques described in SectionÂ 3.1.5, and an appropriately modified version of the above guess-and-check technique will leak the client port and sequence number(s) needed for TCP injection. Linux mitigated this issue in a case-specific manner, replacing per-bucket selection with an IPID generated by prandom_u32 only for SYN/ACKs that are large enough to be fragmented (see Linux commit 970a5a).

3.1.7. Covert Channels

A covert channel is an attack that transfers data between two processes or machines that are not supposed to be able to communicate, e.g., a privileged program leaking data to an unprivileged userÂ (Lampson, 1973). KleinÂ (Klein, 2022) (Fig.Â 2Z) recently demonstrated that both counter-based and PRNG-based IPIDs can be used as covert channels to transmit information from a sender within an isolated network to any external receiver. Although the details differ across OSes and IPID selection methods, the main idea is for the isolated sender to force its outside-facing firewall or host machine to either send a number of packets (signalling a 1 bit) or not (signalling a 0 bit), which the external receiver can view via probe comparison of the firewall/hostâ€™s IPIDs.

Perhaps the most surprising of these covert channels uses PRNG selection with a searchable queue of size kğ‘˜kitalic_k, since PRNG IPIDsâ€™ unpredictability is not a defense in this case. First, the receiver quickly sends kğ‘˜kitalic_k probes to the firewall/host so that the repliesâ€™ IPIDs x1,â€¦,xksubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are exactly those in the searchable queue. The isolated sender then communicates a 0 or 1 bit as described above. Finally, the receiver sends another kğ‘˜kitalic_k probes to the firewall/host to obtain IPIDs y1,â€¦,yksubscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y_{1},\ldots,y_{k}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If there is overlap between the xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s and yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s, some packets must have been sent between the two sets of probes to evict the original members in the queue, likely indicating that the sender communicated a 1 bit; otherwise, if the xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s and yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s are disjoint, the sender likely communicated a 0 bit.

All major OSes except Windows and OpenBSD released patches for these covert channels. \addedIn particular, macOS mitigated this issue by removing the searchable queue from its PRNG selection, abandoning the idea of reserving IPIDs for non-repetition altogether (see XNU v8019.61.5, which introduced the change, and v8792.41.9, which fixed a minor bug for avoiding IPID zero).

3.2. Fragment Injections

In fragment injection, the attacker plants one or more malicious fragments appearing to originate from some trusted source in a target machineâ€™s reassembly buffer. If any of these fragmentsâ€™ IPIDs match that of a legitimate fragmented packet from the trusted source, a malicious fragment may replace a legitimate one during reassembly. This technique has been used to poison DNS caches and forge domain validation certificates (SectionÂ 3.2.1), intercept traffic behind a NAT (SectionÂ 3.2.2), and shift time on NTP clients (SectionÂ 3.2.3). The general template for fragment injection is:

  1. (1)

    Ensure traffic from the trusted source to the target machine will be fragmented (e.g., by spoofing an ICMP â€œFragmentation Neededâ€ packet from the target to the source).

  2. (2)

    Predict the IPID(s) that the trusted source will assign to the packets targeted for fragment injection, potentially using the probe comparisons outlined in SectionÂ 3.1.

  3. (3)

    If needed, use path MTU discovery or other measurement methods to learn the necessary parameters for crafting malicious fragments.

  4. (4)

    Spoof malicious fragments from the trusted source to the target machine.

There is one salient necessary condition for successful fragment injections:

  1. (FI1)

    An attacker must be able to guess, with reasonable probability, the IPID(s) that the trusted source will assign to the packets targeted for fragment injection.

Fragment injections can be viewed as a special case of (de)fragmentation attacks, exploits that abuse a machineâ€™s reassembly buffer size, fragment eviction policy, or reassembly strategy for unintended behavior. For example, a denial of service attack known as â€œteardropâ€ abused the fact that older reassembly methods would fail if fragments overlapped by a few bits (CVE-1999-0015). Similar attacks were successful across every major OS at some point in time (e.g., CVE-1999-0052, CVE-1999-0157, CVE-1999-0431, CVE-2000-0305, and CVE-2004-0744), and modern fragmentation attacks continue to be a concern for IP stack implementations (e.g., CVE-2020-3373, CVE-2020-28041, CVE-2021-3905, and CVE-2023-24821). We focus specifically on fragment injections since these depend critically on IPID selection methods and their predictability.

3.2.1. DNS Attacks

In DNS cache poisoning, an attacker redirects traffic to an IP address of its choosing by replacing a DNS resolverâ€™s cache entry for a valid domain nameÂ (Schuba, 1993). The first cache poisoning attacks exploited the predictability of globally incrementing DNS transaction IDs (TXIDs) in the BIND protocol to trick DNS servers into accepting spoofed DNS repliesÂ (Arce and Kargieman, 1997). But forging entire DNS replies is not necessary for poisoning. Instead, Herzberg and ShulmanÂ (Herzberg and Shulman, 2013a, b) (Fig.Â 2K) showed that poisoning can be achieved by placing spoofed fragments of a DNS response in a DNS resolverâ€™s reassembly buffer. If any of these fragmentsâ€™ IPIDs match that of the real DNS responseâ€”which is easily guessed for globally incrementing or per-destination selectionâ€”a spoofed fragment will be reassembled with the rest of the DNS response, poisoning the cache (see Fig.Â 5 for details).

Palmer and SomersÂ (Palmer and Somers, 2019) (Fig.Â 2T) later refined DNS cache poisoning to succeed on its â€œfirst tryâ€â€”i.e., with a single spoofed fragmentâ€”and Zheng et al.Â (Zheng etÂ al., 2020) (Fig.Â 2V) adapted it to work against DNS forwarders. KleinÂ (Klein, 2021) (Fig.Â 2X) revealed a weakness in the PRNG that Linux used to initialize its per-connection counters and generate per-bucketâ€™s stochastic increments, making DNS cache poisoning possible with per-connection and per-bucket IPIDs as well (see Linux commit f227e3). Finally, beyond using DNS cache poisoning to redirect traffic, Brandt et al.Â (Brandt etÂ al., 2018) (Fig.Â 2R) poisoned certificate authorities to obtain fraudulent certificates for arbitrary domains.

3.2.2. NAT Packet Interception

Gilad and HerzbergÂ (Gilad and Herzberg, 2011, 2013) (Fig.Â 2G) observed that when an external sender Sğ‘†Sitalic_S using per-destination IPIDs communicates with a NATted receiver, it treats the NAT device as its destination and thus draws from the same per-destination counter for all machines behind the same NAT. Thus, if an off-path attacker Ağ´Aitalic_A controls one of the NATted machines Mğ‘€Mitalic_M, it is easy to obtain the senderâ€™s per-destination IPIDs: Mğ‘€Mitalic_M simply pings Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and reports the replyâ€™s IPID to Ağ´Aitalic_A. Attacker Ağ´Aitalic_A also needs the destination port that the NAT uses to map traffic from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S to Mğ‘€Mitalic_M, which Ağ´Aitalic_A obtains by spoofing packets from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S to the NAT with different guessed destination ports until one of them gets to Mğ‘€Mitalic_M, who reports the correct destination port back to Ağ´Aitalic_A.

Attacker Ağ´Aitalic_A can use these exfiltrated parameters to intercept traffic sent from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S to any receiver Rğ‘…Ritalic_R behind the NAT. Suppose a legitimate packet sent by Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is fragmented as (f1,f2)subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2(f_{1},f_{2})( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where f1subscriptğ‘“1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains the destination port for Rğ‘…Ritalic_R and f2subscriptğ‘“2f_{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains the payload. It then spoofs a new first fragment f1â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘“1â€²f_{1}^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT containing the destination port for Mğ‘€Mitalic_M, the attacker-controlled NATted machine. When the legitimate f2subscriptğ‘“2f_{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT arrives, the NAT reassembles it with f1â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘“1â€²f_{1}^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and delivers it to Mğ‘€Mitalic_M, completing the interception. Generalized versions of this attack achieve off-path denials of service against inter-gateway tunnels when the attacker has puppet scripts behind both endpoints.

3.2.3. Shifting NTP Time

Malhotra et al.Â (Malhotra etÂ al., 2016) (Fig.Â 2O) discovered an off-path attack leveraging predictable IPIDs to inject traffic into Network Time Protocol (NTP) clientâ€“server connections and shift time on NTP clients. An attacker first spoofs an ICMP â€œFragmentation Neededâ€ packet from the target NTP client to its NTP server. It then uses the puppet technique of Gilad and HerzbergÂ (Gilad and Herzberg, 2011, 2013) or the canary fragments technique of Knockel and CrandallÂ (Knockel and Crandall, 2014) to accurately predict the serverâ€™s per-destination IPIDs. This allows the attacker to spoof overlapping fragments from the server to the client containing phony timestamps whichâ€”depending on the clientâ€™s reassembly policy for overlapping fragmentsâ€”may get reassembled into the final packet. This attack was never explicitly patched, though Malhotra et al.Â report that only â‰ˆ0.2%absentpercent0.2\approx 0.2\%â‰ˆ 0.2 % of NTP servers and â‰ˆ1.3%absentpercent1.3\approx 1.3\%â‰ˆ 1.3 % of tested NTP clients were vulnerable in 2016. These numbers have likely only decreased as globally incrementing and per-destination IPIDs become less common.

4. Comparative Analysis

SectionÂ 3 chronicled the co-evolution of IPID selection methodsâ€™ OS implementations and the diverse measurements and attacks that exploited them. In this section, we present a unifying mathematical model of IPID selection (SectionÂ 4.1) and use it to compare and evaluate the methodsâ€™ correctness (SectionÂ 4.2), security (SectionÂ 4.3), and performance (SectionÂ 4.4). By parameterizing this comparison by a machineâ€™s expected rate of traffic, we reveal each selection methodâ€™s relative (dis)advantages across a spectrum of use cases. These evaluations form the basis of our discussion and recommendations in SectionÂ 5.

Several works surveyed in SectionÂ 3 include formal modeling of IPID selectionÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2005; Herzberg and Shulman, 2013a; Ensafi etÂ al., 2014; Zhang etÂ al., 2018; Klein, 2022), but focus only on the exploit or target selection method at hand. Similar modeling efforts exist for TCP sequence numbers, where security is analyzed only with respect to specific exploits (e.g.,Â (Qian and Mao, 2012; Cao etÂ al., 2016; Medeiros etÂ al., 2010; Zhao and Shi, 2013)) and performance analyses focus primarily on congestion control (e.g.,Â (Mathis etÂ al., 1997; Padhye etÂ al., 1998; Cardwell etÂ al., 2000)). Our goal, in contrast, is to evaluate all \replacedsevensix IPID selection methods on level footing, providing an intuitive synthesis for practitioners weighing the tradeoffs of different methods.

4.1. Mathematical Model

We model a server Sğ‘†Sitalic_S communicating with one or more clients and analyze properties of the IPIDs it assigns to outgoing packets. To capture the stochastic nature of network traffic, we assume Sğ‘†Sitalic_S sends packets with non-trivial IPIDs according to a Poisson process with rate Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0. We define the â€œunit timeâ€ of this Poisson process as the average time for a packet sent by Sğ‘†Sitalic_S to be routed to its destination and have all its fragments either reassembled or evicted from the destinationâ€™s reassembly buffer.111In practice, unit time can range from âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼10Â ms (a fast ping) to 120Â s (the longest recommended reassembly timeoutÂ (Postel, 1981; Braden, 1989)). Assuming a unit time of 10Â ms and an average packet size of 1,500 bytes, 1Â Kbps translates to Î»â‰ˆ2âˆ’10.2ğœ†superscript210.2\lambda\approx 2^{-10.2}italic_Î» â‰ˆ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 10.2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 1Â Mbps translates to Î»â‰ˆ2âˆ’0.3ğœ†superscript20.3\lambda\approx 2^{-0.3}italic_Î» â‰ˆ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 0.3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 1Â Gbps translates to Î»â‰ˆ29.7ğœ†superscript29.7\lambda\approx 2^{9.7}italic_Î» â‰ˆ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 9.7 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 100Â Gbps translates to Î»â‰ˆ216.3ğœ†superscript216.3\lambda\approx 2^{16.3}italic_Î» â‰ˆ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16.3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and 1Â Tbps translates to Î»â‰ˆ219.7ğœ†superscript219.7\lambda\approx 2^{19.7}italic_Î» â‰ˆ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 19.7 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This time interval is important for two reasons. First, it is the window of uncertainty for adversaries trying to correlate IPIDs obtained by probing Sğ‘†Sitalic_S (SectionÂ 3.1), since other packets that Sğ‘†Sitalic_S sends in the unit time between its reply to some probe and when that reply is received will further change its current IPID value. Second, this is the interval during which fragments in the same reassembly buffer with the same IPIDs may interact, as required for fragment injections (SectionÂ 3.2).

Poisson processes are classically used in network traffic models that prioritize analytical elegance over high-fidelity representation and prediction. Specifically, packet interarrival times are adequately captured by simple Poisson processes when aggregating large-scale traffic, though traffic patterns do exhibit long-range dependence, self-similarity, and other non-stochastic propertiesÂ (Karagiannis etÂ al., 2004). Alternative traffic models such as Markov Modulated Poisson ProcessesÂ (Bhat, 1994; Bali and Frost, 2007) and autoregression modelsÂ (Hosking, 1981; Paxson and Floyd, 1995; Chen etÂ al., 2000) can better capture these time-dependent properties, but are less amenable to the unifying comparative analysis we perform.

4.2. Analyzing Correctness

The intended function of IPIDs is to support unambiguous packet reassembly after IP fragmentation (see SectionÂ 2.1), so any measure of an IPID selection methodâ€™s correctness should capture its ability to assign distinct IPIDs to packets whose fragments would otherwise be indistinguishableâ€”i.e., those with the same source and destination IP addresses, source and destination ports (if applicable), and protocol number. Formally, we say the server Sğ‘†Sitalic_S produces a collision at a client Cğ¶Citalic_C if two fragments in the reassembly buffer of Cğ¶Citalic_C belong to different packets sent by Sğ‘†Sitalic_S but have the same IPID and protocol number. We analyze each selection methodâ€™s correctness in terms of its worst-case probability of producing a collision, establishing a basis for fair comparison across both counter-based and PRNG-based methods.

In the worst case, all packets sent by Sğ‘†Sitalic_S are sent to the same client Cğ¶Citalic_C via the same protocol and are fragmented in transit; thus, every packet has the potential to cause a collision. 4.3. Analyzing Security

SectionÂ 3 categorized numerous IPID-based exploits as probe comparisons and fragment injections. As highlighted by ConditionsÂ PC2 andÂ FI1, the fundamental issue of predictability in IPID generation underlies the success of both types of exploits. These worst case Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s capture the many ways Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» total traffic can be allocated among rğ‘Ÿritalic_r different IPID resources (e.g., bucket counters) surfacing the allocation that makes a given resource maximally predictable. Together, the uniform case emphasizes how the number of IPID resources impacts security while the worst case captures the fundamental predictability of any one IPID resource.

An IPID selection method is optimally secure if its probability of an adversarial guess is exactly g/216ğ‘”superscript216g/2^{16}italic_g / 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., if the adversary can do no better than make its gğ‘”gitalic_g distinct guesses uniformly at random over all possible IPIDs. Per-connection \addedand pure PRNG selection \replacedareis thus the only optimally secure method\addeds, though \replacedper-connectionâ€™s optimalitythis depends on the potentially precarious assumption that an off-path adversary can never infer the status of another machineâ€™s connection counter or downgrade per-connection selection to some less secure method. In contrast, the PRNG-based methods achieve (near-)optimal security based only on the assumption of a sufficiently random, correctly implemented, and well-seeded PRNG algorithm.

Our model confirms the probable success of idle scan attacksÂ (antirez, 1998; Ensafi etÂ al., 2014), predicting near-certain adversarial guesses for globally incrementing selection on any quiet channel (Fig.Â 7, 0<Î»<10ğœ†10<\lambda<10 < italic_Î» < 1). It also confirms that Linuxâ€™s addition of stochastic increments to per-bucket selection obfuscates otherwise predictable counter statuses in very quiet buckets (Î»<2âˆ’12ğœ†superscript212\lambda<2^{-12}italic_Î» < 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for worst-case traffic; Î»<2âˆ’1ğœ†superscript21\lambda<2^{-1}italic_Î» < 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for uniform traffic). However, this obfuscation quickly dissipates as the rate of traffic increases. Surprisingly, per-bucket selection is easier to predict than globally incrementing selection even at relatively low traffic rates (Î»>22ğœ†superscript22\lambda>2^{2}italic_Î» > 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for worst-case traffic; Î»>27ğœ†superscript27\lambda>2^{7}italic_Î» > 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for uniform traffic), revealing a subtle but significant security advantage to having all IPIDs assigned by a single resource. Per-destination selection inherits the worst of both of these methods: it has multiple counters that always increment by one, rendering it the most predictable of all methods over all \addedbut the most extreme traffic rates. Thus, like per-connection selection, its â€œsecurityâ€ lies not in its resilience to prediction but in the difficulty of accessing its counters, which has been subverted before\deletedÂ (Knockel and Crandall, 2014).

4.4. Analyzing Performance

Our final dimension of comparison is performance, measured in both time and space complexity. We perform this analysis in the context of multi-core servers where CPUs may contend over IPID resources. To assess time complexity, we benchmarked each IPID selection method in ten independent trials per number of CPUs câˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,128}ğ‘12â€¦128c\in\{1,2,\ldots,128\}italic_c âˆˆ { 1 , 2 , â€¦ , 128 } on a 128-core (dual-socket AMD EPYC 7713 Zen3), 512 GiB node on Arizona State Universityâ€™s Sol supercomputerÂ (Jennewein etÂ al., 2023). In each trial, we count the number of IPIDs each of the cğ‘citalic_c CPUs assigns to packets in a 10 second period when concurrently and repeatedly scanning over a CAIDA trace of âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼29 million packetsÂ (CAIDA, 2019). Details of our IPID selection method implementations are given in AppendixÂ B.

The average IPID request times and packet throughput rates for each method are shown in Fig.Â 8. Unsurprisingly, per-connection selection is very fast (less than 0.1Â Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼s per IPID request regardless of the number of CPUs). When Linux gets IPIDs for connection-bound packets, it operates in the context of a socket data structure that at most one CPU is accessing per time. Thus, obtaining an IPID is as simple as incrementing the socketâ€™s counter without any need to locate the counter via hashing or manage concurrency control. \addedPure PRNG selection is similarly fast regardless of scale, since each CPU gets its own RNG context. The other methods require concurrency control to protect access to their shared IPID resources, causing their IPID request times to increase with the number of contending CPUs. Among these methods, globally incrementing selection (implemented as a single atomic counter) is the fastest, even when all 128 CPUs contend over it. Surprisingly, it outperforms even the per-bucket implementations whose primary reason for maintaining numerous buckets is to improve performance by reducing contention. Globally incrementing selection is also desirably opportunistic, performing almost as well as per-connection selection in scenarios with very little contention (1â‰¤câ‰¤41ğ‘41\leq c\leq 41 â‰¤ italic_c â‰¤ 4). Per-destination \addedselection and PRNG-based \replacedmethods that reserve IPIDs for non-repetitionselection have similarly poor performance, as their implementations rely on locking a single global resource (the hash table of destination counters, the searchable queue, or the shuffled permutation).

For space complexity, we consider all data structures that a selection method stores between IPID requests (see TableÂ 1). Globally incrementing selection stores a single 16-bit counter. Per-connection and per-destination selection store one 16-bit counter per active connection or destination, respectively. There are âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼3.7 billion unreserved IP addresses and thus there could be at most as many destination counters; the maximum number of connection counters is even larger since connections also consider source and destination ports and protocol numbers. In practice, Windows fixes a \replacedpurge thresholdâ€”212superscript2122^{12}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT destination counters in Windows 10 and 215superscript2152^{15}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Windows Serverâ€”that puts a soft limitâ€œlargeâ€ upper limit on the number of destination counters \addedand 32-bit last access timestamps it stores before purging stale counters, \addedthough this limit can briefly be surpassed between purge sequencesÂ (Klein, 2022, 2024). Linux treats connection counters as acceptably small members of its socket data structures, and implements per-bucket selection by storing one 16-bit counter and one 32-bit last access timestamp for each of its 211superscript2112^{11}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 218superscript2182^{18}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 18 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT buckets. PRNG selection using a searchable queue of size kâˆˆ[212,215]ğ‘˜superscript212superscript215k\in[2^{12},2^{15}]italic_k âˆˆ [ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] stores the last kğ‘˜kitalic_k IPID values generated by the PRNG, plus any data structure used to make searching fast; for example, FreeBSD and XNU search their queues in constant time by storing an array of 216superscript2162^{16}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bits where the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th bit is 1 if and only if IPID iğ‘–iitalic_i is currently in the queue. \deletedFinally, PRNG selection using the iterated Knuth shuffle stores the current permutation of all 216superscript2162^{16}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT IPID values plus one 16-bit index for the next value in the permutation. \addedFinally, pure PRNG selection does not store any information between IPID requests other than the state of its PRNG.

Taken together, \replacedpure PRNGglobally incrementing selection outperforms all but per-connection selection in terms of time and \replaceddoes not use any memory beyond its PRNG stateuses the minimum possible amount of memory; \addedglobally incrementing selection is the runner-up, outperforming the remaining methods while only using 2 bytes of memory. Per-destination selection (with an upper limit on destination counters) and the \addednon-repeating PRNG-based methods have moderate memory footprints, but their global locks are prohibitive performance bottlenecks that cannot be removed without threatening their correctness or security guarantees. Finally, per-bucket selection achieves competitive IPID request times at the cost of potentially large (but bounded) memory usage.

5. Recommendations

Which IPID selection method is best? As is the case for most worthwhile questions, it depends. In this section, we synthesize insights from prior literature with the correctness, security, and performance evaluations of SectionÂ 4 into concrete recommendations for IPID selection best practices.

Many have argued for avoiding fragmentation altogether by explicitly marking packets as atomic when possibleÂ (Kent and Mogul, 1987; Bellovin, 1989; Gilad and Herzberg, 2011; Herzberg and Shulman, 2013a; Malhotra etÂ al., 2016), e.g., when packets are small or the path MTU is discovered as part of a TCP connection. This best practice is already widely adopted. All five OSes we reviewed make packets atomic \addedwhen possible, and 82.4% of packets in the CAIDA trace we used for benchmarkingÂ (CAIDA, 2019) and an estimated 99% of all network traffic is not fragmentedÂ (Shannon etÂ al., 2002).

Recommendation 1.

Any IP packet that can avoid fragmentation (e.g., with a known path MTU) should be made atomic with DF=trueDFtrue\text{DF}=\textsc{true}DF = true, MF=falseMFfalse\text{MF}=\textsc{false}MF = false, and Fragment Offset=0Fragment Offset0\textit{Fragment Offset}=0Fragment Offset = 0.

But making packets atomic does not obviate the question of how their IPIDs should be assigned. RFC 6864Â (Touch, 2013) states that an atomic packetâ€™s IPID can be any value and should be ignored by subsequent machines. This latitude presents a previously unleveraged opportunity to secure not only the atomic packetsâ€”e.g., in the case of forced fragmentation (SectionÂ 3.2)â€”but also the packets that may not be able to avoid fragmentation, such as DNS and QUIC traffic sent via UDP. As we saw in SectionÂ 4, the security and performance of various IPID selection methods depend on the rate Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» of IPID assignment. Choosing whether to assign IPIDs to atomic packets using a fixed value (as FreeBSD, macOS, and Linux do), a dedicated selection method (as Linux does), or the same selection method as for non-atomic packets (as OpenBSD does) changes those methodsâ€™ effective IPID assignment rates, thus also changing their expected security and performance.

We propose a new approach to IPID selection based on user choice instead of OS developer hard-coding. Our analyses in SectionÂ 4 showed that although there is no universally â€œbestâ€ IPID selection method for every use case across all three dimensions of correctness, security, and performance, different methods achieve desirable tradeoffs for specific ranges of outgoing traffic. Thus, in this new approach, OSes would implement several IPID selection methods and expose this choice as a network setting. Users or system administrators would then estimate their rates of traffic to determine their use case and choose methods that best suit their needs, as we describe below.

Recommendation 2.

OS implementations should make IPID selection configurable (e.g., as a network setting), enabling end users and system administrators to choose selection methods for their connection-bound and non-connection-bound packets. Per-connection selection for connection-bound traffic and per-bucket selection for all other traffic can be used as the default configuration.

Suppose, then, that an end user or system administrator can estimate their Poisson outgoing packet rate as Î»=Î»c+Î»nğœ†subscriptğœ†ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘›\lambda=\lambda_{c}+\lambda_{n}italic_Î» = italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Î»csubscriptğœ†ğ‘\lambda_{c}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the Poisson rate of connection-bound packets and Î»nsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›\lambda_{n}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the Poisson rate of all other packets (i.e., non-atomic and non-connection-bound atomic packets). We can use our evaluations from SectionÂ 4 to partition the space of rates (Î»,Î»n)ğœ†subscriptğœ†ğ‘›(\lambda,\lambda_{n})( italic_Î» , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by use case and identify the best IPID selection method(s) for each. See Fig.Â 9 for a visual summary.

Recommendation 3.

IPID selection method(s) should be chosen based on a machineâ€™s expected rates of total outgoing traffic and non-connection-bound outgoing traffic according to Fig.Â 9.

In some of the use cases we describe below, it will be advantageous to assign IPIDs to connection-bound traffic separately from the rest (Fig.Â 9, white hatching). In these situations, connection-bound atomic packets should be assigned IPIDs using per-connection selection, storing connection counters in the corresponding socket data structures. This is preferable to assigning them a fixed IPID value (e.g., zero) since it acts as a low-cost implementation of Postelâ€™s lawâ€”â€œbe conservative in what you send, be liberal in what you acceptâ€â€”hedging against forced fragmentation by a malicious adversary or other machines fragmenting packets downstream in violation of RFC 6848.

It remains to determine, for each use case, the best selection method for non-connection-bound packets and whether this method should also be used for connection-bound packets.

  1. (1)

    Slow Overall (e.g., printers, edge devices, IoT). If the total outgoing packet rate is slow (Î»nâ‰¤Î»â‰¤20â‰ˆsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›ğœ†superscript20absent\lambda_{n}\leq\lambda\leq 2^{0}\approxitalic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î» â‰¤ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ 1Â Mbps), our analysis shows that all methods are \replacedlikelyalmost surely correct; per-bucket and PRNG-based selection achieve near-optimal security; and PRNG-based selection is faster than per-bucket selection as there is little to no CPU contention over IPID resources at these slow rates. Thus, PRNG-based selection can be used efficiently for all packets, regardless of whether theyâ€™re connection-bound (Fig.Â 9, solid orange). The specific choice of PRNG-based method can be left up to user preference. \addedPure PRNG selection has the best performance and security but much worse correctness; between the non-repeating methods, searchable queues use less memory while iterated Knuth shuffles have shorter request times, and larger numbers of reserved IPIDs kğ‘˜kitalic_k achieve better correctness at the cost of slightly worse security.

  2. (2)

    Slow Non-Connection-Bound, Moderate Connection-Bound (e.g., home computers, HTTPS servers handling exclusively TCP traffic). If only the non-connection-bound traffic rate is slow (Î»nâ‰¤20â‰ˆsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›superscript20absent\lambda_{n}\leq 2^{0}\approxitalic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ 1Â Mbps) but the overall rate is too fast for \addedpure PRNG selection to be correct and for non-repeating PRNG-based methods to be efficient (Î»>20â‰ˆğœ†superscript20absent\lambda>2^{0}\approxitalic_Î» > 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ 1Â Mbps), then the connection-bound traffic should be handled separately with per-connection selection so the remaining rate is slow enough to use \addeda non-repeating PRNG-based method efficiently (Fig.Â 9, hatched orange). This achieves near-optimal security for all packet types with high performance.

  3. (3)

    Moderate Overall (e.g., home computers, general purpose servers). In the region of moderate traffic rates (20<Î»,Î»n<210â‰ˆformulae-sequencesuperscript20ğœ†subscriptğœ†ğ‘›superscript210absent2^{0}<\lambda,\lambda_{n}<2^{10}\approx2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_Î» , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ 1Â Gbps), the performance bottleneck of per-destination and \addednon-repeating PRNG-based selectionsâ€™ global locks cause them to scale poorly \addedand pure PRNG selectionâ€™s collision probabilities become unacceptably high. Globally incrementing and per-bucket selection perform much better, and per-bucketâ€™s stochastic increments yield better security guarantees than globalâ€™s sequential increments for these moderate rates. Those stochastic increments add the most noise for low traffic buckets, so connection-bound traffic should be handled separately with per-connection selection (Fig.Â 9, hatched teal).

  4. (4)

    Moderate Non-Connection-Bound, Fast Connection-Bound (e.g., busy general purpose servers). In this use case, we reach perhaps the most surprising result of our analysis: reports of globally incrementing selectionâ€™s disadvantages are greatly exaggerated. Globally incrementing selection not only scales better than all other methods under high contention (other than per-connection \addedand pure PRNG), but also overtakes per-bucket selection in security (recall SectionÂ 4.3 for details). Thus, if the non-connection-bound packet rate is not fast enough to take advantage of globally incrementing selection alone (Î»n<210â‰ˆsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›superscript210absent\lambda_{n}<2^{10}\approxitalic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ 1Â Gbps) but the total outgoing packet rate is (Î»â‰¥210â‰ˆğœ†superscript210absent\lambda\geq 2^{10}\approxitalic_Î» â‰¥ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ 1Â Gbps), then all traffic should be lumped together under globally incrementing selection (Fig.Â 9, solid dark blue).

  5. (5)

    Fast Non-Connection-Bound (e.g., DNS servers). By the same logic as in the previous case, if the non-connection-bound packet rate is fast enough to benefit from globally incrementing selection on its own (Î»nâ‰¥210â‰ˆsubscriptğœ†ğ‘›superscript210absent\lambda_{n}\geq 2^{10}\approxitalic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ 1Â Gbps), then it should do so. To avoid unnecessarily burdening the single global counter and its cache coherency protocol, the connection-bound traffic can use per-connection selection (Fig.Â 9, hatched dark blue).

Altogether, we recommend that OSes implement four IPID selection methods: globally incrementing, per-connection, per-bucket, and a \addednon-repeating PRNG-based method. (Notably, per-destination selection is never recommended, owing to its \addedpoor performance and historically poor security regardless of use case.) Against the benefits of secure and high-performance IPID selection configurable for each machineâ€™s specific use case, the costs of this proposed approach are small: some added code complexity and slight memory footprint inflation. For example, Linux already implements both per-connection and per-bucket selection; adding globally incrementing selection and a \addednon-repeating PRNG-based method would only use \replaced16â€“128Â KiB10â€“129Â KiB (<0.6absent0.6<0.6< 0.6â€“9%percent99\%9 %) more memory.\deleted, depending on the PRNG-based method.

Our final recommendation is a word of caution. In an effort to avoid creating new side channels when addressing old ones, we advise against \replaceddynamically updating IPID selection methods based on real-time traffic ratesmonitoring traffic rates and updating the corresponding IPID selection methods automatically, in real time. In this setting, \replacedan off-path observer could influence a targetâ€™s selection method by varying its probe rate or infer information from sudden changes in a targetâ€™s IPID distributionÂ (Mongkolluksamee etÂ al., 2012)if an off-path observer saw a targetâ€™s IPID distribution suddenly changeÂ (Mongkolluksamee etÂ al., 2012), it would betray a change in traffic rates. \addedInstead, if different selection methods are preferable at different times (e.g., because traffic rates vary due to diurnal patterns or weekdays vs.Â weekends vs.Â holidays), OSes could support user-defined IPID selection method schedules.

6. Conclusion

In this survey, we collected a complete history of IPID-based exploits and the corresponding OS changes to IPID selection, categorizing these off-path measurements and attacks as either probe comparisons aiming to infer information about other machines through changes in IPIDs over time or fragment injections aiming to replace legitimate fragments with malicious ones during reassembly, causing packets to be corrupted or discarded. We then presented the first comparative analysis of all \replacedsevensix IPID selection methods, formally analyzing their relative correctness and security and empirically evaluating their performance. Of these evaluations, the most surprising is that globally incrementing selectionâ€”the first, simplest, and most dismissed of all IPID selection methodsâ€”is in fact the most secure and performant choice for non-connection-bound packets when the rates of outgoing packets are very high. Finally, we proposed a new approach to IPID selection that shifts the focus from developers making the â€œbestâ€ choice for their OS to users making the best choice for their use case across different ranges of total outgoing packet rates and non-connection-bound outgoing packet rates (see Fig.Â 9). It is our hope that further comparative analyses and theoretical evaluations of \deletedother basic networking protocols will reveal similar best practices that can strengthen the correctness, security, and performance of all Internet-connected devices.

A.1.2. Per-Connection and Per-Destination

Per-connection and per-destination counters also increment sequentially and thus must exhaust all IPID values before a collision can occur. Thus, Eq.Â 8 also describes the probability of Sğ‘†Sitalic_S producing a collision at Cğ¶Citalic_C when using per-connection or per-destination selection.

A.1.3. Per-Bucket (Linux)

All packets sent from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S to Cğ¶Citalic_C via the same protocol are hashed to the same bucket, so the total number of buckets has no bearing on the probability of collision. However, bucket counters are not sequentially incrementing like those in the above methods. Instead, Linuxâ€™s stochastic increments make it possible to skip IPID values, cycle back around, and collide in fewer than 216superscript2162^{16}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT packets. Let Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a random variable representing the number of system ticks since Sğ‘†Sitalic_S last sent a packet; thus, the next bucket increment is chosen uniformly at random from {1,â€¦,Î”}1â€¦Î”\{1,\ldots,\Delta\}{ 1 , â€¦ , roman_Î” }. Since packet transmissions occur according to a Poisson process with rate Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î», Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” is exponentially distributed with mean t/Î»ğ‘¡ğœ†t/\lambdaitalic_t / italic_Î», where t>0ğ‘¡0t>0italic_t > 0 is the number of system ticks per unit time. For this analysis, we set t=3ğ‘¡3t=3italic_t = 3, assuming that packets spend âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼10 ms in transit and there are âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼300 ticks/s.222The assumption of 300 system ticks/s is consistent with Arch Linuxâ€™s implementation. Ubuntu is slightly slower, at 250 ticks/s. We chose Archâ€™s larger value because it generates larger stochastic increments and thus higher probabilities of collision, suitable for a worst-case analysis.

Unfortunately, even with these carefully constructed assumptions, Prâ¢[collisionâˆ£N=n]Prdelimited-[]conditionalcollisionğ‘ğ‘›\mathrm{Pr}\left[\text{collision}\mid N=n\right]roman_Pr [ collision âˆ£ italic_N = italic_n ] is challenging to bound analyticallyâ€”let alone to calculate explicitlyâ€”because each event is dependent on all others. Specifically, whether a new IPID produces a collision depends on the stochastic increments that produced all preceding IPIDs. Thus, for the sake of comparison with other methods, we estimate these conditional probabilities by simulating the generation of IPIDs via stochastic increments and then computing the overall probability of collision using Eq.Â 4.2.333A careful reader might observe that the infinite sum in Eq.Â 4.2 cannot be computed directly. A.2.1. Globally Incrementing
