Appendix B Benchmark Implementation Details

AlgorithmÂ 1 details our implementations of the various IPID selection methods for the benchmarking results reported in SectionÂ 4.4. We give some context for our design decisions below.

Globally Incrementing

We assume the single global counter shared by all CPUs is atomic, meaning it can be accessed and incremented by any one CPU without explicit locking. Specifically, we use C++â€™s std::atomic<uint16_t> which implements the necessary cache coherency protocols.

Per-Connection

In practice, Linux handles TCP (connection-bound) traffic in sockets, and each socket data structure contains its own sequentially-incrementing counter. Any time a thread is setting up a packet as part of a TCP connection, itâ€™s responding to a system call that already provided the socket structure as context. So thereâ€™s no cost to â€œlocatingâ€ the connection counter via some kind of hash function, like there is in per-destination and per-bucket selection. Moreover, thereâ€™s essentially no situation in which multiple cores would be contending over the same socket simultaneously. So from the perspective of our performance benchmark, the complexity of requesting a per-connection IPID is as simple as standing up a uint16_t and incrementing it.

Per-Destination

We model our per-destination implementation based on the recent Windows reverse-engineering efforts of KleinÂ (Klein, 2022), maintaining a hash table of \replaced(16-bit counter, 32-bit timestamp) pairs16-bit counters indexed by source and destination IP address pairs. Following the â€œpurge sequencesâ€ that Windows \addedServer (v1904) uses to limit its hash table sizes, we fix \replaceda purge threshold of r=215ğ‘Ÿsuperscript215r=2^{15}italic_r = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entriesÂ (Klein, 2024)the hash tableâ€™s maximum capacity at r=218ğ‘Ÿsuperscript218r=2^{18}italic_r = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 18 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entries (akin to the largest number of buckets that Linux stores). \replacedPurge sequences are initiated and stale entries are removed as described in SectionÂ 2.3.However, we omit the entriesâ€™ last access timestamps that Windows uses to determine if an entry is â€œstaleâ€ since our benchmark assigns IPIDs to packets as fast as physically possible instead of reflecting typical traffic patterns. Instead, during a purge sequence, we simply delete each entry with a fixed probability (50%) to mimic the removal of stale entries. Because adding, removing, and updating destination counters are not thread-safe, we lock the entire hash table for each IPID request. Klein does not report on how Windows handles concurrencyÂ (Klein, 2022), and this appears to the be only solution that eliminates all race conditions.

Per-Bucket (Linux)

For each of the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r buckets, we maintain a counter and a last access timestamp. Following Linuxâ€™s implementation, we locate the bucket for a given packet using the SipHash-2-4 hash function on the packetâ€™s destination and source IP addresses, the protocol number, and a randomly generated \replaced128-bit64-bit hash key. A stochastic increment is generated using the difference between the current time and the last access timestamp, after which the increment is applied and the timestamp is updated. Because multiple packets may simultaneously hash to the same bucket, some concurrency control is needed. Unlike in per-destination selection, however, multiple buckets can be accessed concurrently, avoiding the need for a global lock. We benchmarked two versions of per-bucketâ€™s concurrency control: one which protects each bucket with a lock, and another that follows Linuxâ€™s actual implementation in making each bucketâ€™s counter and last access timestamp individually atomic. The latter allows a race condition where concurrent accesses to the same bucket could generate stochastic increments based on the same last access timestep and then atomically apply them to the same bucket counter. This does not necessarily pose significant issues for correctness or security, but may change the statistical properties of the IPID sequences slightly.

PRNG-based Methods

Our implementation of PRNG selection with a searchable queue directly follows FreeBSD\deleted and macOSâ€™s implementation\deleteds, and our implementation of the iterated Knuth shuffle follows OpenBSDâ€™s. Both of these methods coordinate multiple instructions that must be made atomically: e.g., testing membership of a new IPID in the queue and then enqueuing it, or swapping two IPIDs in the permutation before advancing the permutationâ€™s start index. To eliminate race conditions, we lock access to the associated data structures for each IPID request. \addedOur implementation of pure PRNG selection follows the macOS/XNU implementation, first reducing a 64-bit salt to a 16-bit salt, and then applying this reduced salt to an IPID chosen uniformly at random from among all 216superscript2162^{16}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 16 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values. Since this method does not keep state, concurrency issues can be sidestepped by giving each thread its own random number generator.
